p: The non-mosquito DENV transmission route is infrequent and accidental, but it has great importance for physicians. Several authors have reported cases of transmission without a mosquito vector, which occurred in different ways, including through needles, congenitally, through mucocutaneous exposure, and through bone marrow transplants [ 24]. DENV infection of healthcare workers usually occurs as a result of needle injuries [ 25, 26, 27, 28, 29], while vertical transmission is responsible for dengue fever cases in infants born to a DHF-diagnosed mother [ 30]. A child from Puerto Rico attained DENV-4 via bone marrow transplant and subsequently died [ 31], and DENV-3 was transmitted to a healthcare worker through blood (mucocutaneous exposure) [ 32]. These are only a few examples of non-vector dengue transmission.
